column2: It could be no one else.
column3: It could be no one else.

column2: He was riding a very fine thoroughbred gray Arab horse with a crimson gold-embroidered saddlecloth.
column3: He was riding a very fine thoroughbred gray Arab horse with a crimson gold embroidered saddlecloth.

column2: The battalions shouted "Hurrah!" and "Vive l'Empereur!" Napoleon said something to Alexander, and both Emperors dismounted and took each other's hands.
column3: The battalions shouted "Hurrah!" and "Vive l'Empereur!" Napoleon said something to Alexander, and both Emperors dismounted and took each other's hands.

column2: The crowd unexpectedly found itself so close to the Emperors that Rostov, standing in the front row, was afraid he might be recognized.
column3: The crowd unexpectedly found itself so close to the Emperors that Rostov, standing in the front row, was afraid he might be recognized.

column2: Sire, I ask your permission to present the Legion of Honor to the bravest of your soldiers, said a sharp, precise voice, articulating every letter.
column3: Sire, I ask your permission to present the Legion of Honor to the bravest of your soldiers, said a sharp, precise voice, articulating every letter.

column2: Alexander listened attentively to what was said to him and, bending his head, smiled pleasantly.
column3: Alexander listened attentively to what was said to him and, bending his head, smiled pleasantly.

column2: But we must give him an answer.
column3: But we must give him an answer.

column2: Lazarev! the colonel called, with a frown, and Lazarev, the first soldier in the rank, stepped briskly forward.
column3: Lazarev! the colonel called, with a frown, and Lazarev, the first soldier in the rank, stepped briskly forward.

column2: Napoleon slightly turned his head, and put his plump little hand out behind him as if to take something.
column3: Napoleon slightly turned his head, and put his plump little hand out behind him as if to take something.

column2: Napoleon, without looking, pressed two fingers together and the badge was between them.
column3: Napoleon, without looking, pressed two fingers together and the badge was between them.

column2: Napoleon merely laid the cross on Lazarev's breast and, dropping his hand, turned toward Alexander as though sure that the cross would adhere there.
column3: Napoleon merely laid the cross on Lazarev's breast and, dropping his hand, turned toward Alexander as though sure that the cross would adhere there.

column2: And it really did.
column3: And it really did.

column2: Officious hands, Russian and French, immediately seized the cross and fastened it to the uniform.
column3: Officious hands, Russian and French, immediately seized the cross and fastened it to the uniform.

column2: The Preobrazhensk battalion, breaking rank, mingled with the French Guards and sat down at the tables prepared for them.
column3: The Preobrazhensk battalion, breaking rank, mingled with the French Guards and sat down at the tables prepared for them.

column2: Two officers with flushed faces, looking cheerful and happy, passed by Rostov.
column3: Two officers with flushed faces, looking cheerful and happy, passed by Rostov.

column2: What d'you think of the treat?	What d'you think of the treat?
Tomorrow, I hear, the Preobrazhenskis will give them a dinner.
column3: Tomorrow, I hear, the Preobrazhenskis will give them a dinner.

column2: Yes, but what luck for Lazarev!	Yes, but what luck for Lazarev!
Here's a cap, lads! shouted a Preobrazhensk soldier, donning a shaggy French cap.
column3: Here's a cap, lads! shouted a Preobrazhensk soldier, donning a shaggy French cap.

column2: First-rate!"
column3: First rate!"

column2: It has to be done.
column3: It has to be done.

column2: He must respond in kind."
column3: He must respond in kind."

column2: Boris, too, with his friend Zhilinski, came to see the Preobrazhensk banquet.
column3: Boris, too, with his friend Zhilinski, came to see the Preobrazhensk banquet.

column2: On his way back, he noticed Rostov standing by the corner of a house.
column3: On his way back, he noticed Rostov standing by the corner of a house.

column2: Rostov!	Rostov!
Nothing, nothing, replied Rostov.
column3: Nothing, nothing, replied Rostov.

column2: You'll call round?
column3: You'll call round?

column2: Yes, I will.
column3: Yes, I will.

column2: Rostov stood at that corner for a long time, watching the feast from a distance.
column3: Rostov stood at that corner for a long time, watching the feast from a distance.

column2: He caught himself harboring such strange thoughts that he was frightened.
column3: He caught himself harboring such strange thoughts that he was frightened.

column2: Nicholas ate and drank (chiefly the latter) in silence.
column3: Nicholas ate and drank (chiefly the latter) in silence.

column2: He feared to give way to his thoughts, yet could not get rid of them.
column3: He feared to give way to his thoughts, yet could not get rid of them.

column2: But I never said a word about the Emperor! said the officer, justifying himself, and unable to understand Rostov's outburst, except on the supposition that he was drunk.
column3: But I never said a word about the Emperor! said the officer, justifying himself, and unable to understand Rostov's outburst, except on the supposition that he was drunk.

column2: But Rostov did not listen to him.
column3: But Rostov did not listen to him.

column2: If we are ordered to die, we must die.	If we are ordered to die, we must die.
If we're punished, it means that we have deserved it, it's not for us to judge.
column3: If we're punished, it means that we have deserved it, it's not for us to judge.

column2: If once we begin judging and arguing about everything, nothing sacred will be left!
column3: If once we begin judging and arguing about everything, nothing sacred will be left!

column2: Yes, and to drink, assented Nicholas.
column3: Yes, and to drink, assented Nicholas.
